choices.text: Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery
Right renal vein is longer than left renal vein
Left renal artery is longer than right renal artery
The anterior most structure at renal hilum is the renal artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the anatomy of the kidney?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Right renal artery is longer than left renal artery

 

Option A:

 

Due to the position of the aorta to the left of the midline and the inferior vena cava to the right, the right renal artery must travel a longer distance to reach the right kidney compared to the left renal artery. This is why the right renal artery is typically longer than the left.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: In fact, the left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein because the left renal vein has to cross the midline in front of the aorta to reach the inferior vena cava, while the right renal vein has a shorter and more direct path to the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C: The left renal artery is not longer than the right; it is typically shorter because the aorta lies closer to the left kidney.

 

Option D: In the typical anatomical arrangement, the most anterior structure at the renal hilum is the renal vein. The sequence from anterior to posterior is usually the renal vein, followed by the renal artery, and then the renal pelvis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The right renal artery is longer than the left renal artery due to the relative positions of the aorta and the inferior vena cava, which necessitates a longer course for the right renal artery to reach the right kidney.

 

  1. Left renal vein is longer than right renal vein (hence left kidney is preferred for donor nephrectomy)

  2. Right renal artery is longer

  3. Anterior to posterior structure of hilum: Vein → Artery → Renal Pelvis

 

 

Ref: Sabiston textbook of surgery 20th edition pg 2069

questions.text: Microscopic Hematuria is defined when there are more than?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 3-5 RBCs/hpf

 

Explanation:

 

Microscopic hematuria is a clinical condition characterized by the presence of an abnormally high number of red blood cells in the urine that cannot be seen with the naked eye but can be detected using a microscope or a dipstick test during a urinalysis. It is typically defined as three or more red blood cells per high power field on microscopic examination of urinary sediment from at least two out of three urine samples.

 

Here are some of the conditions that can cause microscopic hematuria:

 

  1. Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): These can cause irritation of the bladder or urethra and result in bleeding.
  2. Kidney Stones: These can breach the lining of the urinary tract as they pass through, causing bleeding.
  3. Glomerular Diseases: Conditions affecting the glomeruli, the filtering units of the kidneys, such as glomerulonephritis or IgA nephropathy, can cause blood to leak into the urine.
  4. Medications: Some drugs, like anticoagulants and anti-inflammatory medications, can induce bleeding in the urinary tract.
  5. Trauma: Blunt/penetrating renal trauma
  6. Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia (BPH): In men, an enlarged prostate can cause irritation or blockage of the urinary tract and result in bleeding.
  7. Systemic Diseases: Conditions such as sickle cell disease or systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can also cause hematuria.

 

Educational objective:

 

Microscopic Hematuria - > 3-5 RBCs/hpf

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1475

questions.text: Identify the imaging modality:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intravenous urogram (IVU)

 

Option B:

 

IVU (Intravenous Urography) Also known as Intravenous Pyelogram (IVP), this is an X-ray exam that uses a contrast dye to visualize the urinary tract, including kidneys, ureters, and bladder. The contrast is given intravenously, and multiple X-ray images are taken at different time intervals to monitor the passage of the contrast through the urinary tract. The image provided shows the presence of contrast within the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, which is characteristic of an IVU (image in question).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: X-ray KUB This stands for Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder X-ray. It's a plain radiograph typically used to assess the abdominal area for the presence of kidney stones, calcifications, or abnormal gas patterns. It doesn’t involve contrast and is often the first imaging test done for patients with suspected kidney stones.

 

 

Option C: Retrograde Pyelogram This is a procedure where a catheter is placed via the urethra, bladder, and then into the ureter. Contrast is injected retrograde (upwards) into the ureter and kidney. This is usually done during a cystoscopy. The image doesn’t indicate this process as there is no visualization of catheter placement.

 

 

Option D: Micturating cystourethrogram: 

Contrast is injected in the bladder via a catheter or intravenously, patient is asked to micturate and X ray is taken. It shows bladder and urethra with contrast.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intravenous Urography (IVU) is an imaging modality that uses intravenous contrast to visualize the urinary system, including the kidneys, ureters, and bladder, on X-ray images taken at different time intervals. It is particularly useful for identifying urinary tract disorders such as obstructions, stones, and tumors.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1475

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with recurrent UTI underwent an IVU as shown below. What is pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ureterocele

 

Option C:

 

Ureterocele A ureterocele is a cystic dilatation of the distal ureter near its insertion into the bladder. It can lead to urinary obstruction and may be associated with recurrent UTIs, which fits the clinical scenario described. On an IVU, a ureterocele may be identified by the "cobra head" sign, which is the appearance of the dilated distal ureter and the surrounding halo of contrast.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: VUR (Vesicoureteral Reflux) Vesicoureteral reflux is the backward flow of urine from the bladder into the kidneys and ureters. This condition often presents in children and can be associated with recurrent UTIs. However, it is inferred from the retrograde flow of contrast (not seen here).

 

Option B: Posterior Urethral Valves This condition is characterized by the presence of abnormal folds of tissue in the posterior urethra, which can cause obstruction and is generally found in male infants. It would not be the pathology in question for a 15-year-old girl.

 

Option D: Cystocele A cystocele occurs when the bladder herniates into the anterior vaginal wall due to weakness of the supporting pelvic floor muscles. It is more common in older women and typically does not present with a 'cobra head' sign on imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of a 'cobra head' sign on the IVU in a patient with recurrent UTIs is indicative of a ureterocele.

 

  • Ureterocele is a cystic enlargement of the intramural ureter, which probably occurs due to atresia of the ureteral orifice.
  • It has a female-to-male ratio of 4:1 and occurs bilaterally in 10% cases.
  • In childhood, they usually present with infection. When large, they can obstruct the bladder neck or even the contralateral ureteric orifice.
  • The classic feature of a ureterocele on an intravenous urogram (IVU) is the ‘cobra head’ sign.
  • The treatment of simple ureteroceles is surgical excision with reimplantation of the ureter.
  • Endoscopic incision of a ureterocele is the preferred treatment method for simple ureteroceles in infants and small children, but may result in subsequent ureteric reflux. A non-functioning kidney may need nephrectomy.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1467

questions.text: Identify the plane that the line marked in the below picture represents:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plane of avascularity

 

Option D:

 

  • The marked structure is Brodel’s line.

 

Plane of Avascularity This refers to a part of the kidney that has a lesser blood supply. The marked line is identified as Brodel’s line, which is indeed an avascular plane along the border between the anterior two-thirds and posterior one-third of the kidney. This plane is utilized surgically because it is relatively bloodless and provides safer access to the renal pelvis or calyces during operations such as nephrolithotomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Plane of Vascularity This would indicate an area of the kidney that has a rich blood supply. However, the marked line is not known to represent a vascular plane, so this is not the correct choice.

 

Option B: Plane of Trauma There is no specific "plane of trauma" in renal anatomy, so this option does not apply to the marked line.

 

Option C: Plane of Cysts/Tumours While cysts or tumors can occur in various places in the kidney, there isn't a specific anatomical plane that predisposes the kidney to cysts or tumors, making this option incorrect for the marked line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brodel’s line represents an avascular plane along the kidney, which is crucial for surgeons to recognize and utilize during renal surgeries to minimize blood loss and avoid damage to the kidney's vascular supply.

 

  • The avascular plane of Brodel is the section of renal parenchyma between 2/3 anterior and 1/3 posterior kidneys on the cross-section that is relatively avascular. The reason for its relative avascularity is that it represents the plane where the anterior and posterior segmental renal artery branches meet.

 

Ref: Online resource - https://radiopaedia.org/articles/avascular-plane-of-brodel

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the urology clinic with a history of recurrent kidney stones. He reports severe pain in the flank area, and imaging studies reveal the presence of multiple renal calculi. The patient has tried various treatments in the past with limited success. The urologist discusses the option of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL) as a treatment for the stones, considering their size and composition. Which type of renal calculi is resistant to Extracorporeal Shock-Wave Lithotripsy (ESWL)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cystine

 

  • Cystine stones are notably resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. Cystine, an amino acid, forms crystals that are both dense and hard, making them less likely to break up under the force of shock waves typically used in ESWL. 
  • This resistance necessitates alternative treatment approaches for effective management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Struvite: These stones, while often large, can be treated with ESWL, although they may require more than one session due to their size and composition.

 

Option C. Calcium oxalate dihydrate: These stones generally respond well to ESWL, although factors such as stone size and location can affect treatment success.

 

Option D. Uric Acid: Uric acid stones are generally amenable to ESWL; however, they are better managed with urinary alkalization as a first-line treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing that cystine stones are particularly resistant to shock wave treatment helps in planning the appropriate management strategy, potentially incorporating alternative methods such as pharmacological treatment or different types of lithotripsy. 
  • This knowledge is crucial for urologists and healthcare providers involved in the treatment of patients with kidney stones, ensuring they choose the most effective and patient-appropriate treatment option.

questions.text: A 64-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with low backache not responding to NSAIDs. His PSA levels are 100 ng/ml, and MRI of the spine shows lytic lesions at L5-S1. A per rectal examination reveals an asymmetrically enlarged stony hard prostate. Which of the following drugs is indicated in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goserelin

 

  • Goserelin is indicated for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer.
  • It is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist that inhibits testosterone production.
  • Prostate cancer is a testosterone-dependent cancer, and reducing testosterone levels is crucial for managing advanced cases.
  • Elevated PSA levels (normal < 4.0 ng/ml) and metastasis to the vertebrae suggest advanced disease, explaining the low backache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Somatostatin: It is not used in the management of prostate cancer; it is used for conditions like acromegaly and certain types of hormone-secreting tumors.

 

Option C. Testosterone: It is contraindicated as it would promote the growth of testosterone-dependent prostate cancer.

 

Option D. Terlipressin: It is used to manage bleeding varices in liver cirrhosis, not prostate cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Goserelin, a GnRH agonist, is used in the treatment of advanced prostate cancer by inhibiting testosterone production.
  • Elevated PSA levels and metastasis indicate advanced disease requiring hormone therapy.

questions.text: A patient was operated on for benign prostatic hyperplasia. On evaluation, incidentally, cancer of the Prostate was detected and on further workup was found to have metastasis. Which of the following drug is used for treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Goserelin

 

  • The treatment for metastatic prostatic cancer is to go for Subcapsular bilateral orchidectomy to reduce the production of testosterone (as prostate cancer is testosterone dependent) (Surgical castration).
  • If patient is not willing for orchidectomy we can give drugs to reduce the testosterone like LHRH.
  • Agonists like Goserelin/Leuprolide (Medical orchidectomy/castration)Top of Form

questions.text:
A 75-year-old male presents with symptoms of increased urinary frequency, urgency, nocturia, and difficulty in voiding. Upon examination, the prostate is smooth and non-tender. What are the storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia?

 

  1. Urgency
  2. Enuresis
  3. Hesitancy
  4. Frequency
  5. Dribbling
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 4

 

  • The storage symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) include urgency, enuresis (involuntary urination during sleep), and frequency (increased need to urinate). 
  • These symptoms arise due to irritation and decreased capacity of the bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 3, 4: Hesitancy is not a storage symptom but a voiding symptom. It refers to difficulty initiating the flow of urine and is more related to the obstructive effects of BPH.

 

Option B. 2 and 5: Dribbling is a voiding symptom related to poor bladder emptying, while enuresis is a storage symptom.

 

Option C. 1, 2, 4, 5: Dribbling is also a voiding symptom, and its presence with the other storage symptoms makes this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with two types of symptoms: storage symptoms (urgency, frequency, nocturia, urge incontinence) due to bladder irritation, and voiding symptoms (hesitancy, poor flow, dribbling, sensation of incomplete emptying) due to obstruction of urine flow. 
  • Proper differentiation between these symptoms aids in diagnosing and managing BPH.

questions.text: ​​​​​Identify the mismatch prostatectomies:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Freyer’s prostatectomy – Perivesical

 

  • Freyer’s prostatectomy – Perivesical is incorrect.
  • Freyer’s technique is a transvesical approach, not perivesical.
  • The perivesical space is the extraperitoneal space surrounding the bladder, and it is not typically entered during a transvesical prostatectomy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Young’s prostatectomy – Transperineal: This is correct. Young's prostatectomy is performed via a transperineal approach.

 

Option B. Millin’s prostatectomy – Retropubic: This is correct. Millin's technique is a retropubic approach to prostatectomy.

 

Option D. Holmium laser prostatectomy – Cystoscopy: This is correct. Holmium laser prostatectomy is an endoscopic procedure performed through cystoscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of open prostatectomies for BPH:

 

  1. Young’s prostatectomy – Trans-perineal
  2. Millon’s prostatectomy – Retropubic
  3. Freyer’s prostatectomy – Trans-vesical

 

Ref: Bailey, 28th Edition, Page no. 1528

questions.text: In performing transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), maintaining urinary continence post-procedure is crucial. Which anatomical landmark signifies the limit of inferior resection in TURP to preserve the external sphincter mechanism and ensure continence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Verumontanum

 

  • This is the correct answer. The verumontanum marks the proximal margin of the external sphincter mechanism, which is essential for continence.
  • Resection beyond this point can damage the sphincter and lead to incontinence.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A: Internal sphincter. The internal sphincter is not the landmark used to determine the limit of TURP; it is located at the bladder neck and not usually visible during the procedure.

 

Option B: Bladder neck. Resection typically begins at the bladder neck, but this is not the landmark for the limit of resection.

 

Option D: Ejaculatory duct. The ejaculatory ducts are located proximal to the verumontanum, within the central zone of the prostate, and are not a landmark for the resection limit in TURP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The verumontanum is the anatomical landmark that marks the proximal margin of the external sphincter.
  • During TURP, resection should not extend beyond the verumontanum to avoid damaging the external sphincter and causing incontinence.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia. Which of these is not an indication to perform TURP?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased frequency

 

Option C:

 

Frequency alone is not a strong indication for prostatectomy.

 

Increased urinary frequency. While urinary frequency is a symptom of BPH, increased frequency alone, without other complications or significant post-void residual, is not a strong indication for TURP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acute urinary retention. This is an indication for TURP when it is caused by BPH and cannot be managed medically.

 

Option B: Residual urine volume greater than 200 mL. Significant post-void residual urine volume indicates inadequate bladder emptying and can be an indication for TURP.

 

Option D: Presence of bladder diverticula. Diverticula can be complications of longstanding BPH due to high-pressure voiding, and their presence can be an indication for TURP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

TURP is considered when a patient experiences complications of BPH, such as urinary retention, significant post-void residual urine, bladder stones, recurrent urinary tract infections, or bladder diverticula. Increased urinary frequency alone is not typically an indication for TURP.

 

Indications for prostatectomy:

 

  • Acute retention
  • Chronic retention and renal impairment: a residual urine of 200 mL or more, hydroureter or hydronephrosis demonstrated on ultrasound, uraemic manifestations and abnormal renal function (accounts for 15% of prostatectomies).
  • Complications of Bladder outlet obstruction: stone, infection and diverticulum formation.
  • Haemorrhage: these patients present with recurrent haematuria with no obvious cause and a very vascular prostate can be seen on cystoscopy.
  • Elective prostatectomy for severe symptoms: this accounts for about 60% of prostatectomies. Frequency alone is not a strong indication for prostatectomy.

 

The natural progression of outflow obstruction is variable and rarely gets worse after 10 years. Severe symptoms not responding to drug therapy, a low maximum flow rate (<10 mL/s) and an increased residual volume of urine (100–250 mL) are relatively strong indications for operative treatment.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1527

choices.text: Anemia due to blood loss

questions.text: An 80-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy complained of dizziness, nausea, vomiting after resection of large prostate by TURP. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Water intoxication

 

Option B:

 

Water intoxication. This is the most likely cause. During TURP, irrigation fluids can be absorbed into the systemic circulation, particularly if large prostatic veins are opened. This can lead to dilutional hyponatremia and water intoxication, presenting with symptoms of cerebral edema such as confusion, nausea, vomiting, and potentially seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Anemia due to blood loss. Although blood loss can occur during TURP and cause symptoms like dizziness, it would not typically cause nausea and vomiting.

 

Option C: Glycine toxicity. Glycine is often used as an irrigant during TURP, and while toxicity can occur, it usually presents with visual disturbances or encephalopathy. It's less likely to cause nausea and vomiting alone.

 

Option D: Hypoglycemia. There is no direct link between hypoglycemia and TURP. Hypoglycemia would not typically be expected as a complication of this procedure unless there was a preexisting condition or medication interaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Water intoxication, or TURP syndrome, can occur postoperatively due to the absorption of irrigation fluids. This can lead to hyponatremia and present with symptoms of nausea, vomiting, confusion, and dizziness. Treatment typically involves fluid restriction and careful management of electrolyte balance.

 

  • Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of TURP can give rise to congestive cardiac failure, hyponatremia and haemolysis.
  • Patient presents with confusion and other cerebral events often mimicking a stroke.
  • The treatment consists of fluid restriction.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1530

choices.text: Seen in children younger than 5 years of age
Treatment is by chemotherapy and surgery

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Wilms’ tumor?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Generally crosses midline

questions.text: Which of these is the best treatment for Polycystic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kidney transplant

 

Option B:

 

Kidney Transplant This is considered the best treatment option for patients with ESRD due to ADPKD. A kidney transplant can restore normal kidney function and is generally performed when a patient's kidney function is significantly reduced or they have reached ESRD.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rovsing's Operation This procedure involves deroofing of cysts and was traditionally used to relieve symptoms in PKD. However, it is not a definitive treatment for PKD, especially as it does not prevent the progression of the disease to end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

 

Option C: Nephrectomy Nephrectomy, or surgical removal of the kidney, may be necessary in cases of severe pain, infection, or massive enlargement of the kidneys due to cysts. It is not a cure for PKD.

 

Option D: Anderson-Heynes Dismembered Pyeloplasty This is a surgical procedure used to treat ureteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, a condition typically unrelated to PKD. Therefore, it is not a relevant treatment for PKD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best treatment for Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) when it progresses to end-stage renal disease is a kidney transplant. Other treatments like Rovsing's operation or nephrectomy may be used for symptomatic relief but do not address the underlying genetic disorder. Anderson-Heynes dismembered pyeloplasty is not a treatment for PKD as it's indicated for UPJ obstruction.

 

ADPKD has variable penetration and approximately 50% of affected individuals eventually develop end-stage renal disease (ESRD).

 

ADPKD – autosomal dominant, systemic disease:

 

  • Rarely manifests before the fourth decade.
  • Hypertension, abdominal pain, haematuria or a palpable flank mass are common presentations.
  • Control of hypertension can delay progression.

 

Best treatment for ADPKD – Kidney transplant

 

Rovsing's surgery – Deroofing of cysts. Not done anymore.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1470

choices.text: Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the ER after falling off a horse. Her vitals are stable, but she complains of pain and tenderness in her lower abdomen and has not passed urine yet. On examination, there is a visible bruise over her lower abdomen, and blood is seen at the urethral meatus. The bladder is not palpable. What is the appropriate management for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy

 

The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible bladder injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and perform suprapubic cystostomy.

 

Trauma to lower abdomen with blood at urethral meatus implies urethral rupture. The most appropriate initial management option for a patient with a possible urethral injury is Wait for the bladder to fill and then do a suprapubic cystostomy.

 

After bladder fills up with urine, a suprapubic cystostomy is done in immediate management of urethral rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wait and send her home: This option is not appropriate for a patient with a possible urethral injury.

 

Option B. Immediate insertion of Foley catheter: This option involves the insertion of a small tube through the urethra and into the bladder to drain urine. This is contraindicated in suspected urethral rupture, as it may create false passage.

 

Option C. Suprapubic aspiration of urine: This option involves inserting a needle through the skin and into the bladder to aspirate urine. This option may be preferred in cases where the urethra is injured or obstructed, making the insertion of a Foley catheter difficult. For this to be done, the bladder should be distended.

questions.text: 35-year-old healthy male is presented with a gunshot wound to the right upper thigh region. On examination, the patient was hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is known as “work-horse” suture material in general surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polyglactin 

 

Polyglactin (commonly known by the brand name Vicryl) is often referred to as the "work-horse" suture material in general surgery. It is a synthetic, absorbable suture that provides reliable strength and is used widely in soft tissue approximation and ligation. Polyglactin sutures are popular due to their predictable absorption time, good handling characteristics, and minimal tissue reactivity, making them versatile for various surgical procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PDS: PDS is used for longer-term support in tissues but is not considered the "work-horse" material due to its prolonged absorption period and different applications.

 

Option C. Linen: Linen is a non-absorbable natural suture that is rarely used in modern practice due to higher rates of tissue reactivity and availability of better alternatives.

 

Option D. Catgut: Catgut is an absorbable natural suture but is less predictable in terms of absorption and causes more tissue reactions than synthetic sutures like polyglactin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polyglactin (Vicryl) is commonly considered the "work-horse" suture in general surgery due to its reliability, predictable absorption, and minimal tissue reactivity.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) TB kidney

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presents with lower abdominal pain, frequent urination, and signs of dehydration. Physical examination reveals abdominal tenderness, and urine analysis indicates sterile pyuria. An image is provided. What is the most likely condition? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Putty kidney

 

  • The given image finding of a putty kidney is suggestive of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB).
  • Putty kidney is characterized by a homogenous and ground glass-like calcification of the kidney.
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria and is always a secondary TB caused by dissemination through the bloodstream.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by a tuberculin test or acid-fast bacilli staining and culture of urine samples.
  • CT urography is the preferred imaging modality for visualizing renal calcifications and assessing the various stages of renal TB.
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs and surgical intervention may be necessary, such as partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nephrocalcinosis: Is the deposition of calcium in the kidney parenchyma or tubules, seen in hypercalcemia conditions like hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Staghorncalculus: Kidney stones are a type of large urinary calculus that takes up a large portion of the urinary collecting area in the kidney. They often present in only one kidney, but in up to 15% of cases, they form in both. They often form due to recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Option D. Psoas calcification: Refers to the calcification (formation of calcium deposits) in the psoas muscle, which is a large muscle in the lower back that plays a role in hip flexion and trunk stabilization. Psoas calcification is not directly related to kidney or urinary system conditions and may have other underlying causes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Putty kidney is a radiographic finding associated with genitourinary tuberculosis, characterized by homogenous, ground glass-like calcifications in the kidney.
  •  This condition typically presents with symptoms such as sterile pyuria, and diagnosis is confirmed through specific TB testing and imaging modalities like CT urography.
  •  Treatment usually involves antitubercular drugs and may require surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man who recently quit smoking, presents with intermittent profuse hematuria and flank pain for 2 months. Abdominal exam shows a left flank mass which is ballotable. Investigation shows elevated serum bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and prolonged prothrombin time. What could be the underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Renal cell carcinoma

 

Option A:

 

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is often associated with hematuria and flank pain and can present with paraneoplastic syndromes such as non-metastatic hepatic dysfunction (Stauffer syndrome), which may manifest with abnormal liver function tests.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While retroperitoneal sarcoma can present with flank pain and hematuria due to mass effect or invasion of the renal parenchyma, it is less commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes affecting the liver.

 

Option C: Angiomyolipoma is typically a benign renal tumor made up of blood vessels, muscle, and fat. It can cause flank pain and hematuria if it is large or bleeds, but it is not usually associated with liver dysfunction.

 

Option D: Malignant melanoma can metastasize to the kidney and cause hematuria; however, it is less likely to cause the liver dysfunction described without evidence of hepatic metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of hematuria and flank pain in a patient with a smoking history, along with evidence of non-metastatic liver dysfunction (elevated serum bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, and prolonged prothrombin time), is highly suggestive of renal cell carcinoma, potentially with associated Stauffer syndrome.

 

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC include:

 

  • Elevated ESR (Most common)
  • Stauffer syndrome - non-metastatic liver dysfunction, characterised by elevated serum bilirubin, ALP and prolonged prothrombin time
  • Hypercalcemia - due to increased PTH related peptide
  • Hypertension
  • Polycythemia
  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Lambert Eaton syndrome

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th Edition pg 1482

choices.text: Surrounding hilar lymph nodes

questions.text: Radical nephrectomy typically involves resection of the following except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Entire ipsilateral ureter

 

Option D:

 

The entire ipsilateral ureter is not always removed in a radical nephrectomy. The decision to remove the ureter is based on the location and extent of the tumor. For example, if the tumor is located at the lower pole and away from the ureter, the ureter may be spared.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Gerota's fascia, the fibrous envelope that encloses the kidney and perirenal fat, is typically removed during a radical nephrectomy.

 

Option B: The ipsilateral adrenal gland is often removed during a radical nephrectomy, especially if the upper pole of the kidney is involved, or if the tumor is large or centrally located. However, in modern nephrectomy practices, the adrenal gland may be spared if imaging and intraoperative findings suggest no involvement.

 

Option C: The surrounding hilar lymph nodes are usually removed during a radical nephrectomy to assess for metastatic spread of renal cell carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radical nephrectomy typically involves the removal of the kidney within Gerota's fascia, the ipsilateral adrenal gland (depending on tumor characteristics and location), and surrounding hilar lymph nodes. The entire ipsilateral ureter is not routinely resected unless indicated by the presence of tumor within it or very close proximity.

 

  • The standard management for stage I or II renal tumours and selected cases of stage III disease is radical nephrectomy.
  • This procedure involves en bloc removal of Gerota’s fascia and its contents, including the kidney, the ipsilateral adrenal gland, and adjacent hilar lymph Nodes.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1483

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child with hematuria and fever is admitted to the casualty. On examination, right side abdominal mass is felt which does not extend over the midline. A CT scan was done which showed a solid mass with cystic areas in the lower and upper quadrants arising from the right kidney. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wilms tumour

 

Option B:

 

In the clinical presentation of a 2-year-old male with hematuria, fever, and a palpable right-sided abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, coupled with a CT scan showing a solid mass with cystic areas in the right kidney, the diagnosis of Wilms’ tumor is likely.

 

Wilms tumor is the most common renal malignancy in children, usually presenting between ages 2 and 5. It typically presents as an abdominal mass that does not cross the midline, consistent with the findings in this case.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Neuroblastoma is a common pediatric malignancy that typically originates in the adrenal gland or paraspinal region. It can present as an abdominal mass and occasionally involves the kidney, but it often crosses the midline and frequently shows calcifications on imaging.

 

Option C: Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that may lead to the development of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the brain, skin, heart, and kidneys. While angiomyolipomas are associated with tuberous sclerosis, they are usually seen in older patients and are not commonly presented as a solid mass with cystic changes in children.

 

Option D: Angiomyolipomas are benign renal tumors composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat. They are seen in adults and are associated with tuberous sclerosis complex. They usually do not present with an acute abdomen or systemic symptoms like fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most probable diagnosis in a young child presenting with hematuria, fever, and a non-midline crossing abdominal mass, with CT imaging showing a solid mass with cystic areas in the kidney, is Wilms tumor. This tumor is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood and is typically treated with a combination of surgery and chemotherapy.

 

Wilms tumour:

 

  • Presentation: The most common presenting feature is asymptomatic abdominal mass. Other symptoms may be hypertension, hematuria and weight loss.
  • Most common primary renal tumours of childhood (2-5 Years) – Wilms tumour
  • Treatment: Surgery and chemotherapy.
  • Neuroblastoma: crosses the midline, shows calcifications on CT
  • Angiomyolipoma: mostly seen in adults.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1485

choices.text: The least invasive technique for diagnosis is ultrasound KUB
Best diagnostic modality to confirm obstructive dilatation is DTPA scan
Retrograde pyelography confirms the site of obstruction
IVU can be used in functional and non-functional kidneys

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of nephrolithiasis presents with severe left flank pain and nausea. Preliminary ultrasound findings suggest hydronephrosis. As his clinician, you consider further diagnostic measures. Which of the following statements about hydronephrosis is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IVU can be used in functional and non-functional kidneys

 

Option D:

 

An intravenous urogram (IVU) can be used to assess the excretory function of kidneys. It is not useful in non-functional kidneys because it relies on the excretion of contrast by the kidneys to outline the renal pelvis, calyces, and ureters. If a kidney is not functioning, it will not excrete contrast, and an IVU will not provide the necessary diagnostic information.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The least invasive initial imaging technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis is ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (KUB). It is non-invasive, widely available, and can quickly identify dilation of the renal pelvis and calyces.

 

Option B: The best diagnostic modality to assess for obstructive dilation within the renal collecting system is a renal scintigraphy scan, such as a diethylene triamine pentaacetic acid (DTPA) scan. This test provides functional information about drainage and can quantitatively assess differential renal function and the presence of obstruction.

 

Option C: Retrograde pyelography is an invasive procedure that involves the insertion of a scope into the urethra and bladder to visualize the ureters and collecting system. It can delineate the site and cause of an obstruction in the urinary tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An intravenous urogram (IVU) is not useful for non-functional kidneys because it requires the kidney to excrete contrast to visualize the urinary tract. For diagnosing hydronephrosis, ultrasound is the least invasive method, a DTPA scan is the best to confirm obstructive dilation, and retrograde pyelography can localize the site of obstruction.

 

IVU can be used only if the kidney is functional.

 

  • Ultrasound is the least invasive technique for diagnosing hydronephrosis.
  • Retrograde pyelography can confirm the site of obstruction.
  • Intravenous urogram (IVU) is helpful only if the obstructed kidney is functional.
  • Renal isotope scan (DTPA or MAG-3 ) is the best modality to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition Pg 1468-69.

choices.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with seizure, recurrent gross hematuria and left flank abdominal pain. Abdominal CT reveals left perinephric hematoma with 3 cm angiomyolipoma along with multiple right renal angiomyolipoma measuring 1.5 to 6.5 cm. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tuberous sclerosis

 

Option C:

 

Tuberous sclerosis is a genetic disorder that causes the growth of benign tumors in multiple organs, including the skin, brain, kidneys, and heart. Renal angiomyolipomas are a common manifestation, along with other systemic features such as seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) Syndrome is a hereditary cancer syndrome that leads to the development of multiple tumors and cysts in different organs. While renal cysts and clear cell carcinoma are common, multiple angiomyolipomas are not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option B: Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD) is characterized by the presence of numerous cysts in both kidneys, which can lead to abdominal pain and hematuria. However, angiomyolipomas are not a hallmark of this disease.

 

Option D: Hereditary Leiomyomatosis and Renal Cell Cancer (HLRCC) HLRCC, previously known as hereditary angiolipoma, is associated with cutaneous leiomyomas and an increased risk of renal cell carcinoma, not angiomyolipomas.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical presentation of seizures, recurrent gross hematuria, flank pain, and CT findings of multiple renal angiomyolipomas is most suggestive of tuberous sclerosis. This genetic disorder is associated with various benign and malignant tumors, including renal angiomyolipomas, and requires a multidisciplinary management approach.

 

 

 Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1456

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with bloody urine for the past 10 days. His urine analysis report shows many RBCs, no casts or crystals. The kidney lesion's typical gross appearance post nephrectomy is depicted in the figure. Which of these hormonal levels could be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythropoietin

 

Option B:

 

Some RCCs can ectopically produce erythropoietin, leading to secondary polycythemia. This condition is one of the recognized paraneoplastic syndromes associated with RCC.

 

  • The gross pathological specimen shows Renal cell carcinoma.
  • 5-10% of RCC produces erythropoietin. This erythropoietin production can lead to polycythemia.
  • Paraneoplastic syndromes (PNSs) are found in up to one- third of patients with RCC. The most common PNS is an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) followed by hypertension, anaemia and hypercalcaemia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cortisol production is typically associated with adrenal tumors such as adenomas or carcinomas of the adrenal cortex, not commonly with RCC.

 

Option C: Ectopic production of thyroid hormones, such as thyroxine, is not commonly associated with RCC. Thyroid function abnormalities are typically related to thyroid pathologies.

 

Option D: Calcium (Calcitriol) RCC can lead to increased production of calcitriol by the tumor, which may cause hypercalcemia, another common paraneoplastic syndrome seen in RCC. However, it is less commonly reported than erythropoietin production leading to polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with renal cell carcinoma, paraneoplastic syndromes can manifest with the ectopic production of hormones such as erythropoietin, leading to secondary polycythemia.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition 1482

choices.text: Posterior urethral valve

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections is admitted with clinical symptoms of fever, dysuria, and cloudy urine for the last 3 months. Urine exam shows significant bacteriuria (>50,000). Which of the following is the most common etiology for chronic pyelonephritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reflux nephropathy

 

Option A:

 

Reflux nephropathy, also known as vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), is a condition where urine flows backward from the bladder into the kidneys. This backward flow can lead to recurrent infections and scarring of the kidney tissue, which is a common cause of chronic pyelonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While renal stones can cause obstruction and recurrent infections leading to pyelonephritis, they are less frequently the underlying cause of chronic pyelonephritis compared to VUR.

 

Option C: The posterior urethral valve is a congenital condition seen primarily in males, which can lead to urinary obstruction and secondary infections. However, it is not the most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis in females.

 

Option D: Urinary TB will show sterile pyuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis, especially in the context of recurrent urinary tract infections and symptoms suggestive of an active infection, is reflux nephropathy.

 

The most common cause of chronic pyelonephritis is reflux nephropathy

 

Reflux nephropathy / Vesicoureteric reflux:

 

Vesicoureteric reflux is back-flowing urine from the bladder to the ureters.

 

Symptoms of vesicoureteral reflux:

 

  • Urgency, frequency of urination
  • Burning when urinating
  • Cloudy urine
  • Fever
  • Pain in the side flank of the abdomen

 

Management:

 

  • Antibiotics and symptomatic treatment
  • Surgical therapy to correct the defect

 

Complications:

 

End-stage renal failure

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1476

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with persistent abdominal pain since a week and fever to the casualty. He has a mass on palpation on the right side of the abdomen. A CT scan is done which shows a mass arising from the right kidney. He undergoes surgery for the same and the mass is excised. Identify the condition from the image shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nephroblastoma

 

Option C:

 

Based on the clinical information provided and the image of the excised mass

 

Nephroblastoma, or Wilms' tumor, is the most common renal neoplasm in children. It presents with a palpable abdominal mass, which may be accompanied by pain and fever, consistent with the child's symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Also known as renal cell carcinoma (RCC), Grawitz tumor is generally an adult malignancy. It is rare in children and does not typically present as a sensitive mass in the abdomen in a 2-year-old.

 

Option B: An angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat. It is typically seen in adults and is often associated with tuberous sclerosis, not commonly presenting as a sensitive abdominal mass in infancy.

 

Option D: A neuroblastoma is a childhood tumor arising from neural crest cells, typically found in the adrenal gland or paraspinal region. While it can present with an abdominal mass, it often crosses the midline, which is not suggested in this scenario. It doesn’t arise from kidney, and is seen in infants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common kidney neoplasm in children, presenting with an abdominal mass, fever, and potential hematuria, is balso known as Wilms' tumor. The management of this condition includes surgical resection followed by chemotherapy based on staging.

 

Wilms tumour/Nephroblastoma:

 

  • It is the most prevalent kidney neoplasm in children.
  • Presentation - palpable, painless abdominal mass (first sign), fever, and hematuria
  • Genetic basis of disease – Modification in WT1 or WT2 genes on chromosome 11, the WTX gene and the AMER1 gene on the X chromosome, and the CTNNB1 gene on chromosome 3.
  • WAGR syndrome: Wilms + Aniridia + Genitourinary abnormalities + Retardation
  • Diagnosis: CECT abdomen- Renal mass without calcification
  • Treatment: Surgery + chemotherapy (National Wilms tumour staging group).

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1484.

questions.text: In complete duplication of ureters, how does the proximal segment insert inside the urinary bladder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Caudal and medial

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ectopic ureters are usually associated with duplicate ureters (in 80% cases)
  • Weigert - Meyer rule of Ectopic ureters:

 

Weigert Meyer rule states that the upper pole ureter is the ectopic ureter and its orifice inserts infero-medially in the bladder in relationship to the lower pole normal ureter.

 

The ureter that drains the upper moiety is at a more inferior and medial position and is prone to obstruction and dysplasia.

 

The ureter that drains the lower moiety is at a more superior and lateral position and is prone to VUR.

 

Educational Objective:


In complete duplication of ureters, the proximal segment inserts into the urinary bladder caudally and medially.

 

﻿Most common symptom:

 

  • ﻿﻿In males - Usually asymptomatic.
  • ﻿﻿In females - Incontinence (paradoxical incontinence)
  • Ectopic opening below the external urethral sphincter leads to urinary incontinence.

 

"continuous incontinence in a girl with an otherwise normal voiding pattern after toilet training is the classic symptom of an ectopic ureteral orifice”

 

Treatment: Reimplantation of ureter is done, if the kidney is scarred.

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1468

questions.text: Identify the procedure done in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) PCNL

 

Option C:

 

PCNL is a minimally invasive surgical procedure to remove kidney stones via a small puncture wound through the skin. This procedure uses a nephroscope, like the imageshown, to directly visualize and remove stones from the kidney.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Cystoscopy involves the use of a cystoscope, which is an endoscopic instrument used to visualize the interior of the bladder and the urethra. It is typically thinner and more flexible or slightly rigid than the instrument shown.

 

Option B: Catheterization involves the insertion of a catheter, a thin flexible tube, into the bladder via the urethra to drain urine.

 

Option D: ESWL is a non-invasive procedure that uses acoustic pulse waves to break kidney stones into smaller fragments. It does not involve the use of an endoscopic instrument like the one shown.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The instrument depicted is a nephroscope used in percutaneous nephrolithotomy (PCNL), a minimally invasive procedure to remove kidney stones by creating a direct channel to the kidney through the skin.

 

The above image is of a PCNL scope used to remove stones by a minimally invasive method.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition Page 1476-77

choices.text: It can lead to a complication called Steinstrasse
Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication
The maximum size of stone removed is 25 mm.
Lower calyceal stones are not amenable to this treatment modality

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute right flank pain. Ultrasound abdomen shows the right renal stone. He undergoes the following procedure. Identify the incorrect statement about the procedure.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The maximum size of stone removed by is 25 mm.

 

Option C:

 

The image shows Extracorporeal shockwave lithotripsy (ESWL) used in treatment of renal stones.

 

ESWL is a non-invasive method introduced in 1980 by Christian Chaussy that allowed stones to be treated on an outpatient basis.

 

Mechanism of action

 

The stone is localised using either fluoroscopy or USG or both. Then acoustic pulse waves are generated and focused on the stone. Stone fragmentation occurs as a result of mechanical stress caused directly by the energy transmitted by the incident shockwave and indirectly by the collapse of bubbles.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: It can lead to a complication called Steinstrasse: Steinstrasse is a German word meaning ‘street of stones’. It describes a row of closely gathered stone fragments that line the distal end of the ureter. This occurs when the stone burden is high or when the stones are hard. These stones are usually asymptomatic and pass spontaneously; however, they may cause obstruction, requiring surgical intervention.

 

Option B: Pregnancy is a contra-indication

 

Option D: Lower calyceal stones are not amenable 

 

Absolute contraindications of ESWL:

 

  •   Pregnancy
  •   Bleeding disorders

 

Relative contraindications of ESWL:

 

  • Pacemaker
  • Distal obstruction
  • Obesity
  • Orthopaedic abnormalities like Scoliosis and Kyphoscoliosis
  • Uncontrolled HTN
  • Aneurysm
  • Renal failure

 

Educational objective:

 

ESWL used for renal stones is best done for stones between 5 mm to 20 mm size, non-lower calyceal stones. Large stones may produce big fragments which may traumatize the ureter leading to “steinstrasse”

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1476

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with a known history of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome presents with acute onset flank pain. A non-contrast CT of the abdomen and pelvis shows the presence of a renal stone which is not visible on the concurrent plain abdominal radiograph. Which of the following is the likely type of renal stone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Xanthine

 

Option A:

 

Xanthine stones are radiolucent and may not be visible on plain radiography. They can be seen in patients with genetic disorders like Lesch-Nyhan syndrome or those with hereditary xanthinuria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Struvite stones, composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate, are typically radiopaque and are associated with urinary tract infections with urease-producing bacteria, such as Proteus mirabilis.

 

Option C: Calcium phosphate stones are usually radiopaque and can be seen on plain abdominal radiographs. They are often associated with metabolic conditions, such as hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option D: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stones and are typically radiopaque on plain radiographs due to their high calcium content.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xanthine stones are a type of radiolucent renal calculus that can be associated with genetic disorders affecting purine metabolism, such as Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, and may not be visible on plain radiographs.

 

Radiolucent renal stones

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1474

questions.text: Upon microscopic examination of a urine sample, a patient is found to have the presence of characteristic crystals. Identify the type of stone, associated with this crystal found in urine analysis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Calcium oxalate stone

 

Option D:

 

The crystals in the image show the classic envelope or octahedral shape, which is highly suggestive of calcium oxalate stones, one of the most common types of kidney stones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Calcium carbonate crystals are less commonly found in urinary sediment and do not typically have the shape shown in the image, which is suggestive of the envelope or octahedral shape characteristic of calcium oxalate stones.

 

Option B: Ammonium phosphate stones, also known as struvite stones, tend to form in alkaline urine and usually present with a 'coffin lid' appearance under the microscope. The crystals in the image do not match this description.

 

Option C: Uric acid crystals can vary in shape, but they often appear as rhomboid or rosette-shaped under the microscope and are usually not as clearly envelope-shaped as the crystals in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The identification of envelope or octahedral-shaped crystals in a urine sample is indicative of calcium oxalate stones, which are a common type of nephrolithiasis.

 

 

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1474

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presents with fever, burning micturition and flank pain presents to casualty. CT abdomen is ordered and the picture is given below. What could be the cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) E. coli

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is a contrast enhanced CT abdomen that shows streaks of gas around the kidney. This is likely to be emphysematous pyelonephritis caused by Escherichia coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most likely cause of emphysematous pyelonephritis, which is characterized by the presence of gas within the renal parenchyma as seen on CT in diabetic patients, is an infection with E. coli. Prompt recognition and treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, along with appropriate drainage, are essential for managing this potentially life-threatening condition.

 

  • Common symptoms: Fever, sepsis, tenderness at the costovertebral angle known as Murphy's punch sign.
  • Treatment- broad-spectrum antibiotics with drainage.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love 28th Ed. Pg 1471.

questions.text: A mother was bathing her 5-year-old child and she felt a lump in the abdomen. The child has also been suffering from repeated bouts of urinary tract infections. An intravenous pyelogram shows the below picture. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Horseshoe kidney

 

Option A:

 

Horseshoe Kidney: This congenital condition occurs when the kidneys are connected at the lower poles by renal parenchyma or fibrous tissue, forming a U-shape. It can be associated with an increased risk of urinary tract infections due to altered urine flow and stasis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Polycystic Kidney Disease:  Polycystic kidney disease typically presents with multiple cysts in the kidneys.

 

Option C: Neuroblastoma: Neuroblastoma is a common abdominal malignancy in children but is usually not associated with the 'flower vase' sign on IVP. It would typically present as a solid mass on imaging studies.

 

Option D: Wilms Tumor: Wilms tumor is a kidney malignancy seen in children and can present with an abdominal mass. While children with horseshoe kidneys have an increased incidence of Wilms tumor, the 'flower vase' sign specifically suggests a horseshoe kidney rather than a Wilms tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 'flower vase' sign on an intravenous pyelogram is indicative of a horseshoe kidney, which is a common renal fusion anomaly and may be associated with recurrent urinary tract infections and an increased risk of renal calculi. Management typically involves treating complications as they arise.

 

  • This is the most common renal fusion anomaly, occurring in about 1 in 400 live births with a male predominance. The incidence of Wilms’ tumour is higher in Horseshoe kidney.

  • Symptoms – Usually incidental.

  • If Symptomatic Abdominal lump in pelvis, recurrent infections and renal/ureteric stones.

  • Treatment: Treat the complications.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1466

questions.text: Identify the surgery shown here:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Boari flap surgery

 

Option B:

 

Boari flap surgery – for ureteric lengthening

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Nesbitt procedure – correction of penile curvature

 

Option C: Young surgery – open prostatectomy

 

Option D: Weigert Meyer surgery – not a surgery. It is a law for duplication of ureters

 

Educational objective:

 

Boari flap surgery is a urological reconstructive procedure used to repair a lower ureteral defect or significant injury. It involves creating a flap from the bladder, which is then tubularized and connected to the ureter to bridge the gap and restore urinary continuity.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery 28th edition page 1480.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections has been referred for further evaluation of possible renal parenchymal damage. The child's blood pressure is within normal limits, and there is no evidence of current infection or obstruction on ultrasound. To assess the renal parenchyma for scarring or structural defects, which imaging modality would be most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DMSA scan

 

Option A:

 

DMSA scan: A DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) scan is a nuclear medicine test that provides detailed images of renal parenchymal tissue. It is particularly sensitive for detecting changes associated with pyelonephritis and scarring.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: DTPA scan: A DTPA (diethylenetriaminepentaacetic acid) scan assesses renal function, particularly glomerular filtration, and is useful for evaluating perfusion and function but not specifically for scarring.

 

Option C: Dexa scan:  A Dexa (dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry) scan measures bone mineral density and is not used for renal imaging.

 

Option D: MCU (Micturating Cystourethrogram): An MCU is a contrast x-ray study of the bladder and urethra that is performed during urination. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), not renal scarring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The DMSA scan is the investigation of choice for detecting renal scarring or structural defects in the kidney, particularly following recurrent urinary tract infections.

 

Renal scarring or structure of the Kidney is best demonstrated by a DMSA scan.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery 28th edition Pg 1459-62.

choices.text: CT scan is often diagnostic of the condition
Most common inheritance – autosomal dominant
It occurs as a result of mutation in one of two genes -PKD1 on chromosome 16 and PKD2 on chromosome 4
Mosty manifests in first or second decade of life

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is admitted with subarachnoid hemorrhage after rupture of a berry aneurysm in the brain. A CT KUB was done as he had hematuria, and it revealed the below picture. Identify the false statement about the condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mosty manifests in first or second decade of life

 

Image shows multiple bilateral renal cysts, suggesting polycystic kidney disease.

 

Option D:

 

Although ADPKD can have a very variable presentation, it most commonly becomes clinically evident later in life, typically not until the third or fourth decades. It is less common for it to manifest in the first or second decade.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: A CT scan is indeed often the imaging modality of choice for characterizing renal cysts, particularly when they are discovered incidentally.

 

Option B: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is more commonly seen compared to autosomal recessive type.

 

Option C: ADPKD is caused by mutations in one of two genes, either PKD1 or PKD2, which are located on chromosomes 16 and 4, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) usually does not manifest clinically until the third or fourth decades of life, and it is caused by mutations in the PKD1 or PKD2 genes. Initial imaging with a CT scan is the modality of choice to evaluate renal cysts.

 

ADPKD rarely manifests before the third or fourth decade of life.

 

It occurs as a result of mutation in one of two genes (PKD1 on chromosome 16 and PKD2 on chromosome.

 

 Risk factors for the development of ESRD are:

 

  • Early age of presentation.

  • HYPERTENSION.

  • MALE sex.

  • ADPKD gene 1.

  • African ethnic group.

 

ADPKD is associated with cysts in other organs, such as the liver, pancreas, arachnoid membranes, and seminal vesicles. It does not usually manifest before the age of 30 years and in some patients, it is never diagnosed.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of Surgery 28th edition pg 1470

questions.text: A 30-year-old male with no significant past medical history presents with occasional mild abdominal discomfort. He denies any urinary symptoms, such as dysuria, hematuria, or nocturia. During a routine health screening, an intravenous urogram (IVU) is performed, which reveals an abnormality. The patient's serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen are within normal limits, and he has no history of urinary tract infections or kidney stones. Based on the IVU findings shown in the image, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Follow up

 

Option D:

 

  • The above image is an IVU of Horseshoe kidney with lower placed kidneys (L3-L5 compared to normal which are at T12-L2) close to midline
  • The IVU shows flower vase sign /handshake sign seen in – Horseshoe kidney
  • Symptoms – Abdominal lump, Dull pain at renal angle
  • Treatment: Symptomatic treatment, no surgery. Surgery is done only for complications (Ureteric obstruction/stones).

 

Regular follow-up is the most appropriate management for an incidentally detected horseshoe kidney in the absence of symptoms or complications. Monitoring should include periodic evaluation of renal function and blood pressure, as patients with horseshoe kidney can have an increased risk of developing hypertension and urinary tract infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rovsing's operation is a surgical procedure for the deroofing of renal cysts in PCKD, not typically indicated for the condition suggested by the IVU findings, which is consistent with a horseshoe kidney.

 

Option B: Isthmectomy with nephropexy may be considered if the patient is planned for abdominal aortic surgeries, which is not present in this case.

 

Option C: Renal Transplant is a treatment for end-stage renal disease or severely dysfunctional kidneys, which is not indicated here as the patient's renal function is normal, and the horseshoe kidney is typically a benign condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate management for an incidentally detected horseshoe kidney without associated symptoms or complications is regular monitoring of renal function and blood pressure. Surgical intervention is reserved for complications such as obstruction, infection, or significant symptomatic concerns.

 

  • It is the most common renal fusion anomaly, occurring in about 1 in 400 live births with a male predominance. The incidence of Wilms’ tumour is higher in Horseshoe kidney.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1466

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with no significant past medical history presents for a routine health check-up. He reports no symptoms and is currently not taking any medications. Physical examination reveals the presence of several cutaneous lesions as shown in the images, including a raised, pebbly area on the lower back and a hypopigmented patch on the upper arm. An abdominal imaging study incidentally identifies a mass in the right kidney. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Angiomyolipoma

 

Option C:

 

  • The picture shown above is of Shagreen’s patch and ash leaf macule seen in Tuberous sclerosis
  • Tuberous sclerosis is commonly associated with Angiomyolipoma of the kidney which arises from perivascular epithelioid cells.
  • Symptomatic Tumours Rx- Partial Nephrectomy
  • Pharmacological treatment: Everolimus

 

Angiomyolipoma Angiomyolipoma is a benign tumor composed of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and fat cells. It is often associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC), a genetic disorder that causes noncancerous tumors to form in many parts of the body, including the skin. The skin findings, such as the Shagreen patch and ash-leaf macules, are characteristic of TSC. Thus, a diagnosis of renal angiomyolipoma would be consistent with the skin findings.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Renal Cell Carcinoma (RCC) RCC is a type of kidney cancer that originates in the lining of the proximal convoluted tubule. It is the most common type of kidney cancer in adults. The associated skin findings in the images are not typically seen with RCC.

 

Option B: Retroperitoneal Sarcoma 

Retroperitoneal sarcomas are a diverse group of rare tumors that arise from the retroperitoneal space. The skin findings depicted are not characteristic of retroperitoneal sarcoma.

 

Option D: Malignant Melanoma Malignant melanoma is a type of skin cancer that can be recognized by its pigmented lesions that may vary in color and have irregular borders. The skin lesions in the images do not resemble typical melanoma. Melanoma can metastasize to the kidney, but this scenario would not explain the skin findings shown, which are indicative of TSC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A patient presenting with a renal mass and specific skin lesions such as Shagreen patches and ash-leaf macules is suggestive of Tuberous Sclerosis Complex, commonly associated with renal angiomyolipoma. These patients may be asymptomatic or may present with symptoms related to the size and location of the tumor. Management may involve partial nephrectomy for symptomatic tumors, and everolimus is used as a pharmacological treatment option.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1416

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is posted for cystoscopy biopsy in a case of suspected bladder cancer. The tumor is found to be invading the muscularis propria of the the bladder wall. What is the pathological stage of the tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T2

 

Explanation:

 

Staging of Ca Bladder:

 

Tx- Primary tumor cannot be assessed

 

T0- No evidence of primary tumor

 

pTa- Non-invasive papillary carcinoma (not invading lamina propria)

 

pTis- Carcinoma in situ

 

pT1-Tumor invades subepithelial connective tissue (lamina propria)

 

pT2- Tumor invades muscularis propria bladder wall

 

pT3- Tumor invades perivesical tissue

 

pT4- Tumor invades any of the following: Prostate, uterus, vagina, pelvic wall and abdominal wall.

 

Educational objective:

 

The tumor invading the muscularis propria bladder wall corresponds to pathological stage T2.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1516

choices.text: Young patient with urethral stricture

questions.text: Which of these is not a contraindication for cystoscopy management of the disease shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Spiculated oxalate stone

 

Option C:

 

Patient is suffering from bladder stones, which is usually treated by cystoscopic litholapaxy.

 

A spiculated oxalate stone refers to a bladder stone with sharp edges or projections, which can increase the risk of injury to the bladder wall during cystoscopic litholapaxy. However, this alone is not a contraindication; rather, it may increase the complexity of the procedure.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Young patients with urethral stricture make it challenging to access the bladder with a cystoscope. This can be a contraindication for cystoscopic litholapaxy if urethral access cannot be achieved safely.

 

Option B: A contracted bladder refers to a bladder with reduced capacity or decreased compliance, often due to chronic inflammation or neurological conditions. Performing cystoscopic litholapaxy in a contracted bladder can increase the risk of bladder perforation due to limited space and mobility.

 

Option D: Large bladder stones, including those composed of triple phosphate (struvite), can pose challenges during cystoscopic litholapaxy, especially if they are too large to be fragmented and removed safely.

 

Educational objective:

 

Contraindications to cystoscopic litholapaxy for bladder stones include failure to access the urethra, presence of very large stones, and bladder pathologies like diverticula or a contracted bladder, but not the presence of spiculated oxalate stones.

 

Contra-indications to cystoscopic litholapaxy:

 

  • Failure to get urethral access: Young patients with stricture urethra, elderly with prostatomegaly.
  • Very large stones
  • Bladder pathologies like diverticula, contracted bladder (Risk of perforation)

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1510.

choices.text: Radical cystectomy for bladder cancer

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image is done along with:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Radical cystectomy for bladder cancer

 

Option B:

 

The image is of ileal conduit urinary diversion.

 

  • An isolated loop of ileum is prepared on its own mesentery, and continuity of the small bowel restored. The ureters are then implanted into the bowel either separately (Bricker) or as one plate (Wallace) and the ileostomy is created. This is usually performed after cystectomy as a bladder substitute.

 

Radical cystectomy for bladder cancer: Radical cystectomy is the surgical removal of the entire bladder, often performed as treatment for invasive bladder cancer. In cases where the bladder is removed, urinary diversion procedures, such as ileal conduit urinary diversion, are necessary to reroute urine from the kidneys to a stoma on the abdominal wall, allowing for continence.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Neurogenic bladder: Neurogenic bladder refers to a dysfunction of the urinary bladder due to neurological damage or dysfunction. While patients with neurogenic bladder may require surgical interventions, such as urinary diversion procedures, the specific procedure depicted in the image, ileal conduit urinary diversion, is typically performed in the context of radical cystectomy for bladder cancer and not specifically for neurogenic bladder.

 

Option C: Ureteric injury during hysterectomy: During a hysterectomy, there is a risk of injury to nearby structures, including the ureters. While ureteric injuries may require surgical intervention, such as ureteric repair or reimplantation, the specific procedure depicted in the image, ileal conduit urinary diversion, is not typically performed in the context of ureteric injury during hysterectomy.

 

Option D: Multiple ureteric calculi: While patients with multiple ureteric calculi may require surgical intervention to remove the stones and relieve obstruction, the specific procedure depicted in the image, ileal conduit urinary diversion, is not typically performed to address ureteric calculi.

 

Educational objective:

 

Ileal conduit urinary diversion is commonly performed as part of radical cystectomy for bladder cancer to reroute urine flow after removal of the bladder.

 

  • The ileal conduit urinary diversion has the lowest rate of complications of all forms of urinary diversion. Risks include uretero-ileal leak or stricture (5%), stomal complications such as stenosis or hernia (20%), upper tract dilatation (30%), recurrent UTIs, and rarely metabolic complications (hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis).”

 

Ref: Bailey 28th Ed. Pg 1518-19.

questions.text: Identify the condition seen in a male child with symptoms of recurrent UTI and difficulty in voiding:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior urethral valve

 

Option B:

 

Posterior urethral valve. This is the correct answer. Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants and can lead to recurrent UTIs and voiding issues. They are obstructive to antegrade flow but can often be bypassed retrogradely by a catheter without difficulty. MCU is the investigation of choice, showing dilated prostatic urethra.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Normal anatomy. A normal VCUG would not show a dilated posterior urethra, which is indicative of an obstructive process.

 

Option C: Urethral stricture. Urethral stricture could cause difficulty in voiding, but it is less common in children and typically does not present with a dilated posterior urethra on imaging.

 

Option D: Urethral trauma. While urethral trauma can lead to stricture and voiding difficulties, it does not fit with the presentation of a dilated posterior urethra on VCUG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior urethral valves are the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants and can lead to recurrent UTIs and voiding issues. They are obstructive to antegrade flow but can often be bypassed retrogradely by a catheter without difficulty.

 

  • Posterior urethral valves are valves with membranes that have a small posterior slit within them.
  • They typically lie just distal to the verumontanum and cause obstruction to the urethra.
  • They function as flap valves; although they are obstructive to antegrade urinary flow, a urethral catheter can be passed retrogradely without any difficulty.
  • Posterior urethral valves need to be detected and treated as early as possible to minimize the degree of renal failure.
  • Investigations include a voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG), which shows a dilated posterior (prostatic) urethra,
  • Treatment is by endoscopic valve ablation

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1539

choices.text: Transitional Cell Ca Bladder

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of ovarian cancer treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy presents to the emergency department with frank hematuria. An ultrasound of the kidneys, ureters, and bladder (USG KUB) reveals a chronic contracted bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radiation induced cystitis

 

Option C:

 

Radiation-induced cystitis. This is the correct answer. Radiation-induced cystitis is a complication of pelvic radiotherapy that leads to endothelial damage, perivascular fibrosis, and eventual bladder contraction. It is consistent with a history of radiation treatment and presents with symptoms such as hematuria.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Metastasis to the bladder. While patients with a history of malignancy can have metastasis to the bladder, this typically presents with more focal lesions rather than a generalized bladder contraction.

 

Option B: Transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. This type of bladder cancer can present with hematuria, but it would not typically cause a contracted bladder on imaging.

 

Option D: Chemotherapy-induced cystitis. Certain chemotherapy drugs can cause cystitis, but they typically cause acute inflammation rather than chronic bladder contraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Radiation-induced cystitis is a late complication of pelvic radiotherapy, characterized by a contracted bladder and presenting with hematuria. Treatment options include symptomatic management, cystoscopic interventions, and potentially more radical surgeries like urinary diversion or cystectomy for severe cases.

 

  • Radiation cystitis is a common complication of pelvic radiotherapy with incidence rates ranging from 23% to 80%.
  • Radiation treatment causes endothelial cell damage and perivascular fibrosis, resulting in ischaemia and obliterative endarteritis.
  • Haematuria is a common symptom.
  • The end stage is a small, fibrotic bladder
  • Rx- Cystoscopic management with fulguration or laser to bleeding vessels OR urinary diversion with or without cystectomy can be performed for end-stage cases.

 

Ref: Bailey and Love’s short practice of surgery 28th edition pg 1514

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with hard painless testicular swelling. On investigations Alpha fetoprotein is 3080. No abdominal lump is felt. USG shows testicular mass with uniform echotexture and small areas of necrosis. Surrounding structures are normal. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High inguinal orchidectomy

 

Option C:

 

  • Given scenario of testicular mass with raised AFP is suggestive of testicular malignancy.
  • Initial treatment of suspected testicular tumour is high inguinal orchiectomy, which involves removal of the testicle and spermatic cord at the level of the inguinal ring.
